b"b' incremental compile dependency check is very slow'"
b"b' Running the compile on a multi-project build with no changes is very slow (around 30+ seconds). I ran yourkit on it
column11: the patch below takes my time down to 1 second. diff git  index cc791 100644+++ @@ -262
column13: 7 @@ final class Execute[A[_] <: AnyRef](checkCycles: Boolean
column14: triggers: Triggers[A])      dependencies( node ) foreach { dep =        def checkForward = onOpt( (node) ) { _ contains dep }        def checkReverse = onOpt( (dep) ){ _.toSet contains node }        def checkReverse = onOpt( (dep) ){ lst =        assert( done(dep) ^ ( checkForward && checkReverse ) )      }  }'"

b"b' That part of the code (in Execute) is only used for assertions.  You could also try disabling all assertions completely.  (In the build
column11: change the argument to -Xelide-below to something like 3000). What stamps are you talking about?'"

column10: b'b" The Source objects it seems to be checking are dependencies from my other sub-projects.  Given that sbt already checked for changes in that dependent sub-project
column11: it seems like sbt shouldn\'t have to to run through the  to do the explicit check. I was looking at the Analysis class and saw the stamps
column12: I assumed they were used to shortcut external dependency checks as well as internal
column13: binary and product.  (But I now see they are not). Does that make sense?  I\'d really like to get the SameAPI checks down
column14: as right now it\'s faster to do an old xsbt compile when nothing\'s changed... I\'ve been looking at wrapping the Source objects with a file hash to shortcut the checks
column15: do you think that\'s a productive avenue? Thanks again"'

column10: b'b" The problem is that source file hashes are insufficient.  It is possible for a class file from the same source file to be different due to binary or source dependencies changing.  Source tracks this information.  Now
column11: you could hash all class files that came from the source.  I think that will work.  I don\'t know how expensive that will be
column12: though. As for why it checks the api in other projects
column13: consider projects A and B
column14: with B depending on A.  B needs to know the Source for A when B was last compiled
column15: not when A was last compiled.  It isn\'t important whether the source files for A have changed or not.  What is important is whether the Source has changed since the last time B was compiled.  Make sense? If you are sure the API comparison is a bottleneck
column16: we can probably generate a unique ID for each API when it\'s created and use that to shortcut things for the common case where the API hasn\'t changed at all.  If you want to look at doing this
column17: let me know.  Otherwise
column18: I\'ll do it.  Either way
column19: thanks for the work you have done so far on this."'

column10: b'b" Thanks
column11: that makes a bit of sense.  I\'ll have to poke around a bit more to get my head around it completely. I\'m pretty sure that\'s the bottleneck
column12: but I\'ll re-benchmark as soon as I finish porting the plugins I need. Thanks again!"'

column10: b'b" Apparently
column11: you are supposed to paste in a gist and link to it
column12: which is somewhat unfortunate. The cause of the problem is that by default
column13: sbt uses the  directory in the project you start sbt in and in particular
column14: the Scala files there.  So
column15: when you move between projects
column16: sbt sees a different version of scalafor c (the one in  and then in ) and thinks the source needs recompiling. There are two solutions I can think of.  First
column17: you can have a global boot directory that is shared by all projects on your machine.  You can do this by setting the system property in your launcher script.  It can also be passed directly to the sbt script to just try it out at first.  For example: The other option is to have another project that refers to the three projects and then always run sbt on that project.  This other project doesn\'t have to contain the subdirectories."'

column10: b'b\' Having a common SBT boot directory sounds like it might be generally goodpractice in any case
column11: because it would minimize startup times for newprojects as well. I\\\'ll give that a try
column12: thanks!On Jun 5

column10: b'b\' Ok
column11: it required running \\\'compile\\\' first to see the error.  The cause was a bad fix for #82.  An empty classpath should be declared with -cp "" because omitting it puts the current directory on the classpath.  scalac then traverses all of the directories in the current directory looking for class files (even though -2.9.0.1/classes/... isn\\\'t a valid package name).\''

column11: Missing dependency \'class \'
column12: required by ./-2.9.1/ This happens only if the project is compiled first
column13: then doc is called. If the target directory is removed
column14: and then doc is called
column15: then the task will succeed. The stragest thing is that the doc task is picking up on compilation units from other projects. In effect
column16: when publishing large project
column17: it\'s pretty much guranteed that there will be some package objects somewhere in the target dir
column18: causing doc task to fail. Stranger yet
column19: adding a dummy dependency to a failing project via dependsOn(dummyProject) fixes the issue. Of course
column20: this depenency becomes an ivy depenency and gets published
column21: so it\'s not a viable workaround. I will attempt to add a sample project as an attachment to the ticket. If it does not work
column22: please contact me via email to get a copy of the sample project that replicates the bug (it\'s been reduced to a couple of files)."'

b'b" I\'m not sure if this is actually the cause
column11: but / has been deprecated since 0.11.0 in favor of the new approach
column12: which fixes things like this.  I added a warning so this deprecation is more widely known. url  url "'

column10: b"b' So
column11: what does that mean for global plugins? How is this issue solved by that warning?'"

column10: b'b" / as implemented in 0.10.x tried to use global plugins as a binary dependency
column11: but this was problematic.  This was fixed in 0.11.0 by making the global plugins project a source dependency of the plugin definition.  This was a fairly invasive change and I didn\'t want to make it automatic.  It turned out that the plugins/ directory was no longer needed and its contents could now go directly in project/
column12: simplifying things. So
column13: to allow users to transition smoothly
column14: the old behavior was kept around and used if the / directory exists and the new (corrected) way gets used if no plugins/ directory exists. The change was documented
column15: but the warning message makes it more obvious that an old
column16: deprecated way is being used."'

column11: so if your global plugins aren\'t  any more
column12: it may come from a directory still lying around in your project
column13: right? I\'ll keep my eyes open to see if this is the only cause of the plugin problems I had."'

column10: b'b\' This Is actually a fundamental issue between ivy and maven.  The primaryissue is that a maven local cachr isn\\\'t really a maven repository (at leastthe variants that ivy expect do not hold true)
column11: so adding the maven localrepo for resolution is an easy way to corrupt the ivy cache. Besides ousting ivy (something we\\\'ve been seriously considering)
column12: I\\\'m notsure there\\\'s an alternative solution we can deliver faster.  requests welcome!On Oct 7

column10: b"b' @jsuereth without transforming this thread into a (very unpleasant and irrelevant)  religious war
column11: how serious are you guys about switching to Aether instead of Ivy? I know that moving would cause things to be drastically simpler for both myself and likely for a lot of the folks building things like IDE integration (for example).'"

column10: b'b\' @dpratt I\\\'d say we\\\'re very very serious about getting rid of Ivy. There\\\'s more than one option on the table.  At this point
column11: we\\\'re not positive of the final solution.  There are a few "requirements" on the table we want to make sure are met by whatever we move to.  Seamless integration with maven is but one of them.  THe other is seamless integration with our existing ecosystem
column12: which is lacking in Aether right now (We\\\'d have to customize it heavily to handle the current sbt plugin publishing situation).  In addition
column13: we\\\'re concerned with what Adept has labelled \\\'variants\\\' on artifacts. Whatever we do will need to solve users needs
column14: and we\\\'ll have to decide soon.  Once we figure out which basket to throw our \\\'variant\\\' needs at
column15: you\\\'ll see some quick developments. For now
column16: any interim solution proposed and delivered from the community is highly welcome.  If I had any good ideas that didn\\\'t lead to intense pain for the user
column17: I\\\'d try them out myself.  \''

column10: b"b' @felipegs AFAIK no.  Ivy first downloads artifacts into its cache
column11: then exposes the files for sbt to use. A lot of work sbt has done with Ivy has been around improving the cache via turning off features or tweaking settings to try to keep it stable.'"

column10: b"b' Download artifacts in parallel'"
b'b" It appears SBT doesn\'t download artifacts in parallel.  Consider the followingPlay framework has 3 repos by defaultIn Australia
column11: ping times times to  repos are 200ms (at least)If an artifact is not found in any repo (for example
column12: when looking up source artifacts)
column13: that could total up to 6 round trips
column14: or 1.2 seconds
column15: just to ascertain that an artifact can\'t be found.Running play eclipsify from scratch
column16: I can count on it taking about 10 minutes just to download everything
column17: even with a 20mb/s internet connection
column18: it\'s the round trip times that kill me. Downloading in parallel would go a long way to help mitigate this.  Checking repositories for artifacts in parallel would help even more."'

column10: b"b' url '"
b"b' Does this just download the artifacts in parallel
column11: or does it also download the artifact metadata (poms
column12: ) in parallel?  Downloading the artifact metadata in parallel would be a significant improvement
column13: the thing that kills us the most is when you have many resolvers
column14: and each one has to be tried before it finds the metadata.  For example
column15: with a 250ms latency (standard trans pacific ping times)
column16: and an average of 4 resolvers to be tried
column17: it will take an average of 1s per artifact to resolve.  In practice it takes longer
column18: due to having to create new connections
column19: ssl negotiations
column20: etc.'"

column10: b'b" @jroper Another thing that could help is if we could get Ivy to expand the graph in parallel
column11: when possible. Checking multiple repositories in parallel may actually lead to more network hits
column12: but it still is only partial parallelism
column13: as we\'ll still only be checking for one dependency at a time
column14: rather than doing a more thorough (and parallel) graph expansion."'

column13: logging setup and properties is non-trivial: the "" property is magical. The JVM tries to load the logging configuration really early during startup

b'b" The actual custom logger code isn\'t important.  What is important is how  finds that code.  If you are implementing  and a configuration file specifies a class name
column11: what class loader would load that class from? It might try to be too smart like ObjectInputStream
column12: but I\'d guess it tries the application class loader.  This class loader can access everything on the classpaths directly passed to java.  However
column13: the classpath passed to Scala is not in this loaderit is in a child class loader that Scala creates.  So
column14: how would  find that class loader?  I\'m guessing it doesn\'t and that\'s why you see this problem. The best confirmation I found on this is actually from [API docs]url  from a logging wrapper by @bmc.  His advice is in this situation is: use something better like Log4j (or presumably its successor Logback). Going forward

column10: b"b' Separate dependency phase'"

b'b" Move dependency extraction to separate compiler phase called that can be run independently from class file extraction that is performed by phase. This pull request serves as foundation for more deep changes were we switch to dependency extraction performed by incremental compiler. This is pure refactoring that does not change behavior. One would wonder if moving logic that traverses contents of to earlier phase could affect behavior because might be populated by later phases. I verified this manually by grepping compiler code and checking where that field gets modified. It turns out that there are two places where is mutated:in typer (and dependency phase runs after typer)in mixin where it add dependency on symbols corresponding to Since we are running before mixing we won\'t see those Symbols but that does not matter because sbt\'s tracking is not fine-grained enough to run into problem of tracking trait symbol but not tracking implementation class symbol."'
b'b" 1.  Do you intend to move the location of the extraction phase or will it always be right after the api phase?  If it will always be after the api phase
column11: there isn\'t a need to make it a separate phase and deal with the ordering problems
column12: right?2. There are now two and calls per source file.  I\'m pretty sure they aren\'t used internally anymore though
column13: so they should probably just be removed.  Alternatively (or additionally)
column14: there isn\'t a problem with dependency lookup being done with class file extraction; it is just the call to that needs to be moved
column15: right?"'

column10: b'b" 1. Yes
column11: I was planning to collapse dependency phase along with api phase but I wanted to keep them separate for now for debugging purposes (Scala compiler has nice capabilities to do per-phase logging). I\'d collapse them once everything stabilizes and I was planning to do that in a few weeks so you can treat this as a transition setup.2. Yes I was wondering about and  . The API callback doesn\'t do anything special with them so it wasn\'t really clear to me what\'s their purpose. I can deprecate them on the interface and remove calls to it. How does it sound? When it comes to dependency extraction you are right. We need to determine the set of Symbols (as with call to  ) early on but we don\'t need to map them in earlier phase. However
column12: alternatively we would have to capture that set for each compilation unit
column13: store somewhere (probably in  ) and then in Analyzer phase map to class files. Do you see any advantage of derring mapping symbols to class files?"'

b"b' Do not  type in api extraction phase'"
b'b" In summary
column11: this series of commits:drops type normalization in api phasefixes #726 and adds test case covering itfixes #736 and adds test case covering itaddresses problem with main method detection after  dropping type dealiasing As explained in #736
column12: the api phase cannot  typesbecause it might miss changes to structure when two type aliasesthat dealias to the same type are involved. It turns out there\'s no test case that breaks if we remove type apart from main method detection. The main method detection implemented by has a designflaw because it works with data structures that representstructure of Scala program extracted by API phase. That phase runs beforeerasure so it extracts unerased
column13: Scala types. However
column14: a main method isdefined in terms of JVM bytecode types so detection should be implementedby scanning the bytecode and not Scala types. That would involve addingsupport for bytecode scanning and rewriting the whole Discovery object.Instead of doing that I decided to just add detection of  type in addition to type.In order to do that I had to hack methodimplementation. This hack doesn\'t make it any worse as it was alreadyhacked in rather arbitrary fashion. Dropping type normalization also fixes #726 by not running intostale cache in Scala compiler problem described in SI-7361."'

column10: b'b" Greg I\'m nervous that this change is user facing
column11: particularly for SNAP.  I\'m going to issue a test case of our external-to-core-sbt use of Discovery. Also
column12: I\'m rather concerned about the fallout of the switch to how names are sanitized to only include String. This is the current mechanism of writing any kind of integration testing code that inspects the current state of the project for available classes (well
column13: in fact any task that wants to grab available classes
column14: like run-main).  You may be pushing the aliased-name madness from the compiler on all sbt users. That\'s what the original method was intended to avoid. In any case
column15: I\'ll get you a test case ASAP."'

column10: b'b" @jsuereth: thanks for review and pinging me. Yes
column11: I\'d like to see a test case which my change breaks. As I demonstrated with my own test case incremental compiler cannot dealias type for _correctness_. I don\'t know what\'s the exact contract of Discovery that it _tries_ to implement but to me the design of that whole file is broken. As I mentioned in commit message
column12: main method is a jvm-level concept and we try to use Scala types to model it. This a doomed to fail or require elaborate logic (essentially: reimplementation of type erasure). Type aliases are not madness of Scala compiler
column13: they are types as any other."'

Discussions on implementation and discovery should be here.  I will wait for Josh\'s links and tests for discovery before commenting there.  I will separately comment on this PR and #736."'

b"b' Private def with existential type causes spurious recompilation due to name instability'"
b'b" Consider the following code Now
column11: let\'s introduce a _private_ method to so it looks like this: If we recompile we would expect one iteration of compilation (just to recompile  ) because the newly introduced method is private. At the moment
column12: incremental compiler will decide to recompile as well because it sees changed signature of method. The reason its seen as changed is name instability for existential types introduced with widlcard syntax. What happens is that Scala compiler has a global counter for ids per compilation unit and uses that counter for naming existential types. Therefore even private definition can affect a signature a public definition thus causing spurious recompilation."'

column10: b'b" Probably due to 864580aae1c32041beccfcf61cb2b545b80c9579.  The correct approach was removed because it relied on
column11: which is apparently an unreliable implementation detail.  The id didn\'t need to be stable across runs
column12: but was just used to identify equal type parameters.  I don\'t remember the details
column13: but should it be desirable to restore the indexed approach
column14: perhaps a Symbol map would work instead."'

column10: b'b" Thanks for the pointer! Yes
column11: using  would solve that particular problem but would introduce a lot more other problems. I was thinking about introducing some kind of a map on Sbt side. I\'m not sure if is the best idea because it means we need to allocate new symbols. Allocating symbols is a side-effecting operation (e.g. it mutates the owner) so it\'s dangerous to do. I was thinking about introducing a much more specialized map which would just deal with remapping names of symbols corresponding to existential type variables. However
column12: synthesizing strings that are both stable and guarantee no collisions is rather difficult."'

column10: b'b" Not that everything isn\'t a side effecting operation
column11: but in general owners know nothing of their children. It doesn\'t mutate the owner unless you mutate the owner (perhaps entering it into the owner\'s scope.)"'

column10: b'b" The problem is in the specs2 runner: url  The fingerprint that is provided to the framework is only guaranteed to be a SubclassFingerprint or AnnotatedFingerprint and not the exact subclass provided by the framework initially.  When not forking

column12: but when forking
column13: it isn\'t because we can\'t (and don\'t want to) assume the user\'s fingerprint type is Serializable."'

column10: b'b" I build a lot of projects. I can\'t work around this by making adjustments of that kind. What I would like to know is why the behavior manifests in this way. Okay
column11: let\'s say the cache is corrupt
column12: either in the most horrible way possible or the most subtle way possible
column13: whatever is the worst case. How does that lead to sbt repeatedly downloading the identical artifacts without noticing or emitting any kind of message? Because this should be sbt\'s responsibility one way or another. Either sbt is an active participant
column14: or sbt is trusting something without verification that we can easily see requires verification."'

column10: b'b\' It\\\'s quite hard to refine what the issue is if the environment is not stable
column11: and also quite hard to reproduce. A few notes:1. Ivy is the one doing the downloading. Sbt has bent over backwards to try to ensure this only happens when necessary
column12: some of which involves making Ivy pretend that artifacts downloaded from different URLs may be the same thing.2. The launcher is responsible for downloading portions of the cache
column13: and sbt\\\'s ivy library the rest.  There may exist subtle differences here
column14: especially across sbt boundaries.  0.13 involved a change whereby scala is pulled using Ivy
column15: rather than the launcher.  This was done so that it _would_ redownload -SNAPSHOT when there was a new -SNAPSHOT available.  I have no idea what happens if you cross between 0.12 + 0.13 at this point
column16: albeit to say that I do this all the time and I haven\\\'t experienced the issue.  I _do_ stick to the same launcher version.3. -SNAPSHOT is _already_ a bit of a foreign concept to Ivy
column17: so its behavior has been less than ideal.  My guess is that somehow the file you\\\'re downloading the and "timestamp" in the ivy cache are consistently out of date when your cache goes sour. If you can provide a reproducible test case
column18: we can try to figure this out.  Also noting the version of sbt you\\\'re using is helpful. Here\\\'s the output of my attempt to reproduce on Mac OSX (just to ensure we\\\'re at least close to the same in terms of environment):  \''

column10: b'b\' Can you tell me what the presence or absence of the line "resolver=sbt-chain" in a file like ivydata-2.10.3.properties means?\''
b'b\' Sbt tries to ignore the resolver used in the cache.  Ivy
column11: by default
column12: caches files pulled from different named resolvers (read repository names) such that if you download from one resolver
column13: that does not mean you have the file if that resolver doesn\\\'t show up in your build. Unfortunately
column14: this makes "proxy" repositories useless
column15: so we attempt to disable that feature.  IF you\\\'re swapping between sbt versions (i think 0.12.x and 0.13.1) you may be hitting a point where the cache is bad due to that file. If you can find a way to wire into ivy
column16: for realsies
column17: that it should ignore that whole subsystem
column18: please do. As far as detecting whether the cache is broken
column19: presence of that resolver isn\\\'t sufficient AFAICT.\''

b'b" Okay
column11: and here is the rest of it
column12: the true killer: once it is asked for a scala SNAPSHOT
column13: it forgets about all the release versions which exist in the ivy cache. This is what led me to say it has nothing to do with snapshots that\'s not quite nothing but it\'s enough to let me see 2.10.3 downloaded hundreds of times. Note that I never call update explicitly and all of this is with sbt 0.13.1 and java 7.  "'

column10: b'b\' What it feels like is this: timestamps are being compared to invalidate snapshots. But that comparison is being applied to release versions as well
column11: so if there is a SNAPSHOT with a more recent time than ANY version
column12: even a release like 2.10.3
column13: then the "older" one is considered out of date and redownloaded.\''

b"b' Incremental compiler misses change to value class
column11: and results to NoSuchMethodError at runtime'"

column11: (without value class) : Change to  to following: From sbt shell
column12: (without )### problem  ### notes does not occur if is executed first.'"

column10: b"b' Do you know which sbt or Scala version did this behavior start?'"
b"b' Maybe from the beginning. following all combinations failed. url url  sbt0.11.3
b'b" @gkossakowski This looks like something maybe for 0.13.3.  I\'ll let you figure out when you think we should tackle it."'
b"b' Not sure I understand. This is a bug in Scala compiler and not sbt
column11: right?'"

column10: b'b" Oh sorry
column11: I misread it. It\'s a genuine bug."'

column10: b'b" I looked into this and the problem is quite fundamental. Incremental compiler detects changes to APIs (and triggers recompilation) based on  signatures as viewed at pickling phase. Pickling phase represents signatures before erasure. That means
column11: if you have: and you change to be a value class the signature of method won\'t change. It will be still  . However
column12: the erasure of is very different if is a value class (it erases to whatever value class wraps). Given the fact that incremental compiler looks only at pre-erasure types
column13: it has no why of noticing the difference. The most principled solution would be to index all signatures twice:at pickling phaseafter erasure (or posterasure
column14: so value classes are completely erased) We would have to introduce a whole new tree walk that indexes all the types. However
column15: that would be very expensive to do especially given the fact that #1078 is not fixed yet. The alternative would be to introduce a special case for value classes and index references to them separately. Specifically
column16: when indexing TypeRefs
column17: we would capture the fact whether a class is a value class. This solution is a bit ugly but cheap to implement and execute (performance overhead would be minimal)."'

column10: b"b' This is definitively 0.13.3 material.'"
b"b' Scheduled for sbt 0.13.6.'"
b"b' Rather than introducing a new compiler phase to capture signatures at erasure
column11: it would be possible to modify the existing API collection phase to look compute the erased type signature of each method it looks at. This approach is much less expensive than a new compiler pass
column12: as you are just doing work more eagerly that would be done later on in the compiler anyway. There is a risk that changing the order that this happens could trigger a data race in the compiler
column13: but some testing with a few big projects would likely flush out that sort of problem.'"

column10: b'b" Another update.  hadoop-mapreduce-client-jobclient has the parent pom hadoop-mapreduce-client.  When that pom is processed
column11: the CustomPomParser adds the sbtTransformHash and namespace to it.  Then the ivy2 PomModuleDescriptorParser adds the parent pom\'s extra info to the -jobclient pom.  That\'s where it gets the sbtTransformHash.  Finally
column12: when the -jobclient gets transformed
column13: the transformedByThisVersion check sees the inherited tag and skips addExtra.  That leaves the sbtTransformHash but doesn\'t add the necessary namespace."'

b"b' Reducing PermGen usage in sbt'"
b'b\' I tracked down a PermGen leak in sbt
column11: which can easily be worked around (although other PermGen leaks may exist). The full story is below
column12: but in short object finalizers are not called frequently enough by the VM (in jdk 6 and 7)
column13: causing classloaders to survive long past their time. The solution is adding after the parts of runTask that create a new classloader
column14: in order to launch Scala or other utilities
column15: the sequence: That must be done from an enclosing stack frame that no longer contains any reference
column16: direct or indirect
column17: to the generated classloader (note that escape analysis was not generally on by default in jdk 6). The complete
column18: albeit condensed explanation
column19: is:Each time sbt invokes the Scala compiler
column20: by creating a new classloader
column21: the classloader is not released.the classloader is kept in the heap by means of a chain of links involving weak references. In particular
column22: when the garbage collector runs and frees the referent from a weak reference
column23: the referred instance may still being tracked if some finalization is still pending.if finalization is not run promptly
column25: and its permgen cannot be released.file descriptors
column28: and sbt uses a lot of them.the jdk 6 and 7 are quite lazy when running finalizers. If there is still heap space
column29: they will not rush to complete finalization in order to free memory. The VMs will not notice that PermGen is slowly running out.as a net result
column30: I saw cases in which there are more than 47\\\'000 file descriptors lying idle in the system
column31: indirectly keeping classloaders from being reclaimed
column32: and leading some code to crash despite being given 1GB of PermGen.adding an explicit invocation to runFinalization()
column33: following the exact sequence described above
column34: will solve the problem. The first gc() causes the referent of the WeakReferences to be released
column35: and tracks the newly freed finalizable objects. The runFinalization() call forces the jvm to deal with those instances immediately. Finally
column36: the second gc() will deallocate them. Once the file descriptors are freed
column37: the weak references are also freed
column39: and therefore its PermGen space is in the end also freed. More in general
column42: and files (even if you close them)
column43: manual invocations to runFinalization() will be needed
column44: or you will get leaks that may show up as "Too many files" or "PermGen Error".  Java 8 replaces the PermGen with a "Meta" space
column45: but it is still subject to leaks. However
column47: which avoids this issue. Java 6 and Java 7 are both affected.\''

column10: b"b' Order of magnitude performance regression in watch mode'"
b'b" The performance of SBT\'s watch mode seems to have regressed across multiple releases
column11: with a significant regression occurring since 0.13.1. I\'ve used the Play code base as a benchmark
column12: on OSX
column13: with 4 CPU cores. I\'ve used from Play\'s directory to estimate the number of source files being watched. I\'ve used as the test to run
column14: and then monitored the process CPU usage in  . On SBT 0.12.4 (Play 2.2.x branch
column15: 482 source files)
column16: uses a fairly steady 20% CPU. On SBT 0.13.1 (Not on any branch
column17: but at the ad306013fe6b2566f328bff3f41ff325d5a269a7 commit
column18: 521 source files)
column19: uses approx 40% CPU
column20: fluctuating between 23% and 70%. On SBT 0.13.5-RC1 (Play master
column22: I\'m seeing use between 150% and 250% CPU
column23: seemingly averaging around 200%. Either adding more files for SBT to watch increases the amount of CPU consumed exponentially
column24: or there\'s been some very serious regressions. This has been reported by other users (at least one user on Linux): url  This makes me very wary of ever giving control of watching files over to SBT. Related: #1223"'

column10: b'b" I\'ve captured some profiling snapshots between SBT 0.13.1 and 0.13.5-RC1

column13: the only methods they show taking any serious is the main call heirarchy.  If anyone knows how to better read these than me
column14: then I\'ll be happy to send the data."'

b"b' Abstract over dependency kind in Analysis'"
b"b' Work in progress to make it easier to add new kinds of dependency. Please see this discussion : url '"
b"b' How about binary dependencies ? How would you represent them ?'"

b'b" I think binary dependency is another kind of dependency edge. You would have You would have to verify what happens when we refer to a class file from a jar. Do we get a path to just a jar file or something else? In a separate comment I\'ll outline what I think remains to be done."'
b'b" Analysis have three methods that manipulate dependencies:
column12: . The takes internal dependencies as parameter. I think we could just have take dependencies of all kinds and deprecate the rest. I don\'t see any use case for adding dependencies after a source has been already added. In other words
column13: would become central method that takes the following information about single src:src location (File)api representationstamp (which lets one to check if source has changed since the stamp has been)all dependencies of given source Once refactoring is done
column14: the only thing that is not tracked by would be  . I don\'t see any reason why they shouldn\'t be tracked by so we could add a TODO for that. It would be that is responsible for dispatching dependencies to right places (e.g. marking external apis as it\'s done in at the moment. I think the same story would apply to where we would unify all methods manipulating dependencies into just one method. As I mentioned above
column15: I think binary dependencies should be refactored as well especially because macros can introduce binary dependencies too. To sum up
column16: I think we should have one method for manipulation dependencies both in and in  . Let me know if that makes sense."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t think merging products into dependencies is a good idea. After all
column11: products (class files coming out of source files) are not dependencies of source files. When I made a comment before saying should handle I meant it should have an additional parameter for taking list of products. Martin
column12: could you update your PR accordingly? There\'s also an interesting problem with the fact that all dependencies are marked as  . It\'s done intentionally so we refactor code in the future without worrying about the fact that they are part of private API. However
column13: _public_ methods in take classes with restricted visibility. Those public methods (like addSource) can\'t be called from outside of package. I don\'t think this is a big deal because most people would just read what is in an Analysis and not try to manipulate it. However
column14: we have to clearly document that new methods for manipulation of Analysis can\'t be called from outside of package. If somebody comes up with a use case of manipulating Analysis then we\'ll have to put a bit more work into this issue."'

column10: b"b' [0.13.7] Natural whitespace parsing breaks XML'"
b"b' Found using community-build url ## steps  ## problem  ## notes Scala allows series of XML nodes as NodeSeq. /cc @ajozwik'"
b'b\' hm.. i\\\'d just use xml:group and remove that "feature" from scalac...\''
b"b' This issue remains open
column11: and the fix is to bump up the Scala version to 2.10.5. This issue was originally discovered using community-build during 0.13.7 development. The workaround #1671 was implemented. This however caused subsequent issues such as #1738 (XML  of arbitrary (0.13.7))
column12: which were discovered after 0.13.7 shipped.  Later it was identified to be Scala compiler issue [SI-9027: Semicolon is not inferred after a XML node sequence literal]url  During 0.13.8 development we decided that sbt should roll back the workarounds put in by #1671 (#1765)
column13: and tell people to use parens or semicolon. SI-9027 was fixed in #4185
column14: and was backported to 2.10.5 in #4186.'"

b'b\' Multiple parallel compilation processes cause "Could not create directory .."\''

b'b" It seems like there is a race condition in SBT which is triggered only by plugins that cause multiple compilation processes to run in parallel. See:url url  I\'m trying to figure out what is going wrong in these cases
column11: to see if there is a workaround other than  . The full stack trace looks like:  "'

column10: b'b" Isn\'t this a bug in sbt-multi-jvm?"'
b"b' No
column11: the above stack trace is from a system without installed. It seems like and have encountered the exact same bug
column12: without sharing any code (other than itself). That suggests to me that either there is some race condition in that only these two plugins are encountering
column13: or that they have both made the same mistake in usage. If you know the internals
column14: are you able to give us any pointers as to what might be causing this or how to fix it? Thanks'"

column10: b"b' /cc @gkossakowski '"
b'b" The stracktrace suggests that you are trying to run two tasks in parallel on exactly the same project. Nothing good can come out of that. Why this is being done? PS. From initial inspection
column11: I don\'t think this is incremental compiler specific. It just compilation takes a long time so races are easiest to encounter when running  ."'

column10: b'b\' My guess would be that is asking SBT to compile the classes with instrumentation
column11: and SBT is scheduling that work in parallel with the regular compile as it doesn\\\'t know that they are mutually exclusive. How can we tell SBT not to do the tasks in parallel? I guess we need to "tag" the tasks
column12: as per [url  Maybe the Compile task should be pre-tagged with and have a default of  ? I think that SBT is cloning its instrumented compile task from the basic one
column13: so that fix should solve things for and any future projects with the same issue? If that sounds like a likely fix
column14: I can look into that.  Is there an easy way for me to verify that two tasks are being run at the same time?Is there an easy way to see what has declared two tasks
column15: to verify my above guess?\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m constantly hitting this with sbt-scoverage as well. Adding "parallelExecution in ScoverageTest := false" does not work as a workaround. Just a FYI.\''
b"b' +1 my Jenkins builds at work are failing randomly due to this bug
column11: probably because of Scoverage'"

column10: b"b' :+1: me as well.'"
b'b" In most cases
column11: shouldn\'t the task use as many CPU cores as possible to compile as many things it can in parallel? If there\'s a race condition on a task
column12: ideally we should look into separating the resource contention (like creation of a directory) rather than reducing parallelism."'

column10: b"b' @eed3si9n
column11: incremental compiler (and Scala compiler) is single threaded so should use one CPU core. My impression is that you get race condition because you are asking to do the same work twice and you get two threads stepping on each other.'"

column10: b'b" @gkossakowski In this case
column11: I\'m talking about multiple executions of tasks against different targets like configuration or subprojects. Does compiler being single-threaded preclude multiple executions of in general?"'

column10: b"b' You can compile separate sources into separate target directories as long as you use separate instances. Incremental compiler takes care of that.'"
b'b\' +1 because my Jenkins jobs at work are failing sporadically (more frequently under high load) with this bug. And I\\\'ve already set "parallelExecution in Global := false".\''
b'b\' Do you have multiple projects targeting the same "target" directory for classfiles?  That could definitely lead to this race...\''
b"b' No
column11: every sub-project has its own target directory for classfiles.'"

b'b\' This one is a big problem for groups like mine which use Play 2.3 and have multi module applications. Play 2.3 introduced an asset jar that is produced by creating an artifact with the "assets" classifier. We have sbt projects that depend on a base project and its assets
column11: so I include those in the sub project with: When we publish new versions of the base to nexus and then rebuild the sub project
column12: only the main jar is downloaded to the ivy cache
column13: the assets jar is never updated once it\\\'s in the ivy cache. This seems to have nothing to do with the updateOptions cached resolution flag introduced in 0.13.7. This behavior seems to exist in 0.13.5 as well
column14: I couldn\\\'t go back before that without more major changes to the project build so I didn\\\'t check. The only workaround I have come up with for now is to use something like sbt-dirty-money to delete the file from the ivy cache before update. Thanks for your attention on it
column15: I looked at the code but I\\\'m not sure where I could jump in to fix it
column16: given the fact that there are several issues with SNAPSHOT and classifier resolution
column17: combined with the cachedResolution settings. Do you have any update on if this is likely to be fixed soon?\''

column10: b"b' IntegrationTest settings should be  for AutoPlugin usage'"

b'b\' I am trying to write an AutoPlugin that provides some source generation in IntegrationTest configuration. The task added by the AutoPlugin gets removed. Here is a minimum  needed to reproduce the problem Produces If you look at the second last line it only prints out "source generated in settings" but not the "source generated in plugin".\''
b'b\' The issue is actually in  . These are added _after_ the autoplugin settings
column11: and the notion of "itSettings" should probably be translated into Autoplugins
column12: so you can depend on their existence.  The workaround right would be to put the itSettings into your autoplugin and not specify them manually on projects. Going to retitle this.\''

column10: b'b\' The calculation of dynamic revision likely happens prior to the conflict resolution between the nodes. So effectively is the same as writing  . Between 1.5.0-beta.2 and 1.4.7
column11: 1.5.0-beta.2 will win because of eviction. So if you want 1.4.7 to be used
column12: the interpretation of cannot be "the latest (on the Internet) that is greater than  ." Instead it needs to change to "the latest (within the current dependency graph) that is greater than  ."\''

column10: b"b' That makes sense. Do you still think the current one is the intended and expected behaviour?'"

column11: but don\'t have a clear answer here.  ### side note  The general issue of dependency conflict (diamond problem
column12: conflict resolution
column13: dependency hell etc) is an universal problem.  JVM tools like sbt / Ivy let user _over-specify_ the module dependency to a version number (due to culture or lack of good index?). Strict interpretation of the dependency quickly fails
column14: so the tools implemented lenient (automatic) _conflict resolution_ algorithms. Using Ivy
column15: we interpret to be an advisory that you want version  . This is now _under-specification_ because this would admit backward incompatible modules. Eviction warning url  is my attempt at swinging the pendulum back to more stricter side.  More complete solution might be: Allow modules to declare version semantics. Easier version range notation like that used by npm such as and url  Dependency manager that is able to resolve version ranges efficiently. Fail resolution when the constraints are not satisfied
column16: and let the user override them.  Interestingly the users of the tools that uses the above range-and-strict combo seem to be asking for lenient resolution anyway (e.g. url  so the grass might always look greener on the other side. "'

column12: this is utterly important. We can add this information to a module ID.  I think this is a bad idea. We should be using ordinary semantic versioning. JS and other programming languages need that solution because the community does not respect semantic versioning. Allowing this notation will complicate the current situation
column13: not make it easier
column14: and it\\\'s not necessary once you specify the semantic versioning that a module uses. We don\\\'t need more ways to express dependencies.  Dependency lock file will help here.  @clhodapp I don\\\'t like your proposed message
column15: it\\\'s utterly verbose. People that don\\\'t know about semantic versioning and dependency conflicts should look it up. Also
column16: this:  is not accurate. There is no way you can have two versions of the same library in the same classpath. The problem comes when a library depends on another library whose version has been changed
column17: and whose JVM classes have suffered binary changes (therefore changing their ids and causing all sort of linkage issues).  Remember that
column18: currently
column19: this message is shown every time there is an eviction between minor bumps of a given version
column20: *even though it may be safe*. The issue is that the whole Scala community is divided between two different versioning schemes: the one from Java (the normal semantic versioning) and the "Scala" one ( ). Sbt assumes the latter one (which we should change). I know that @sjrd has had several issues in the ScalaJS ecosystem because ScalaJS has not ever broken binary compatibility in 0.x.x series.  The major problem when it comes to evicted warnings is that there\\\'s not a general way to reason about version numbers for Scala modules. We should try to change that
column21: and stick with only one way of versioning artifacts. I will open a thread in Scala Contributors about this. \''

column10: b'b\' @eed3si9n There are always going to be constituencies for everything from "it should resolve everything magically" to "any conflict should be an error." What everyone can agree on is that if it threatens not to work
column11: the reason should be made clear. This is addressable in a general way
column12: so I\\\'d say it makes sense to focus on that.  Given the soft semantics of artifact versioning and the absence of any direct analysis of the true differences between versions
column13: the rest is at best solvable by letting people choose their preferred poison. I think it would be a disaster to introduce version ranges. As observed by @jvican
column14: the core issue is that versions don\\\'t have any consistent meaning. The meaningfulness of a version range is not the sum of the versions it contains it\\\'s the minimum
column15: or worse.\''

column10: b'b\' @jvican  I disagree with the bulk of your last comment
column11: partially on factual grounds and partially just based on opinion.  First
column12: the factual stuff: This isn\\\'t true: @chris-martin I were pasting examples of what might be shown for a theoretical task or command
column13: which would replace (to be less jargon-y). This is absolutely untrue. The classpath is just list of places for the system classloader to look for classfiles
column14: including directories and jar files. The default system classloader has absolutely no notion of whether two jars constitute "two versions of the same library" or not. It just goes down the list
column15: searching each location until it finds (a version of) the desired class. Side-note: If you know exactly what order things will be in on the classpath
column16: it is actually _not_ non-deterministic to have two versions of the same library present. It\\\'s just that it\\\'s generally not  particularly _useful_  (one will generally mostly shadow the other and render most unshadowed classes unlinkable). Also
column17: sbt does not make knowable classpath ordering a goal. Therefore
column18: it is both useless and non-deterministic in practice to allow multiple versions of the same library onto the classpath _when using sbt_.  Now the more opinion-oriented stuff. I feel that this is basically saying "If users are not already familiar with this other world-theory
column19: they are inadequate. Seeing this warning (which makes no reference to the world-theory in question) should prompt them to learn all about it and solve their inadequacy". I think that\\\'s counter-productive. I believe that people who use a tool for a while should be naturally pushed toward actually understanding the potentially-dangerous tradeoffs that the tool is making for them and that the tool should do its best to help them gain that understanding. At the very least
column20: I believe that this information should be available under e.g.
column21: and that the user should be directed to run that comand for more info when they view the conflict report. While I agree that version ranges are a bad idea
column22: I don\\\'t think that trying to get the entire community to shift to semantic versioning (and assuming that they just  _have_ after some cutover date in the future) is a very good solution. Instead
column23: what if we added some sort of MiMa-verified "binary compatibility manifest" to the set of files that may be produced when an artifact was published? The details would have to be worked out
column24: but sbt could pull down one or more compatibility manifests during the dependency resolution process and use them to decide what warnings / errors to display to the user? This way we wouldn\\\'t have to enforce any particular versioning scheme on everybody
column25: the community could gradually transition to a more robust system
column26: and binary compatibility breaks would be much more manageable for well-behaved projects. (I actually have other ideas for less-well-behaved projects
column28: but I\\\'ll save those for another context
column29: as implementing them wouldn\\\'t really affect sbt).\''

column10: b'b"  I resisted suggesting any of the many
column11: many technical measures which are available here because I figured the most likely result of doing so would be slowing things down.  But yes there are many
column12: many technical measures available. And there\'s no reason to wait years (or forever) until most jars have incorporated binary compatibility manifests. All the bytecode is sitting there
column13: or could be. Just look at it. Sbt could run mima! But I have a strong feeling it\'s a bad idea to bring any of this up."'

column10: b'b" I have a feeling that doing as much resolve-time MiMa-ing as would be required to never show spurious warnings would have too high a cost. It\'s possible that it would at least be ok to do a comprehensive bytecode-level check when specifically requested
column11: though.  Point taken about the potential for discussions of technical solutions to derail things.. the rabbit hole goes pretty deep. And of course two versions can always be binary compatible and still have incompatible semantics. It\'s just that I think that technical solutions *are* the general way toward a robust future for this stuff
column12: especially in a typed
column13: complied language like this."'

column10: b'b"  No
column11: this is true. Currently
column12: will show any eviction warning produced by the  . Have a look at the implementation url   What you describe is what happens when there is only one user of the library and yes
column13: there is shadowing among jar entries. I misrepresented what I wanted to say.  Let\'s start again: You have two options: 1. Different jars of the same library are binary compatible. 2. Different jars of the same library are binary incompatible.  In the first one
column14: there is no issue
column15: shadowing of jar entries will make sure the first jar entry has always more priority than the second jar entry.  In the second one
column16: though
column17: there is a big issue. If there are more than two users of one library
column18: there will be a clash. Imagine user 1 links from jar 1.2.0 and that will link all its transitive dependencies from its constant pool. Now
column19: user 2 links  (which is defined in 2.0.0) and depends on a binary incompatible  . When the JVM tries to load in the same namespace as the previous
column20: it will fail.  I don\'t think this behaviour is undefined. If you\'re gonna tell the users that message above
column21: why don\'t tell them the full story?  I\'m all in for changing the message as you can see from my previous message. But I disagree with you on which message to show. Let me explain why.  There are different levels of knowledge
column22: if a kid wants to learn how to solve an equation
column23: he better understands algebra first. Educating is good. But only in the right scenario. Your comprehensive message should be shown per users\' request: by typing
column24: for instance. But it should not be shown every time I do and sbt resolves dependencies
column25: because a significant percentage of the users hacking on Scala are familiar with the inner workings of the JVM.  I think this is a great idea
column26: but it has the same problem as semantic versioning: adoption. If you\'re gonna take the time to create such a solution
column27: why not bother enforcing a simpler policy such as semantic versioning?  I have a proposal together with @sjrd to make a semantic version scheme for Scala that covers both binary and source compatibility. I\'ll make it public soon in [Scala Contributors](-).  However
column28: your proposal has two more weaknesses:  * MiMa is far from perfect and there are binary changes that won\'t be caught. Versioning jars is something that requires human intelligence (for now) and cannot be automated. I think that semantic versioning is a good way to reason about binary incompatible changes. In fact
column29: it only describes that. People that want to express more than that in a version number are doing it wrong. * You cannot know whether two jars are binary incompatible from the version number. This is bad to diagnose dependency problems.  All this wouldn\'t happen if we agree on some standards
column30: and we enforce them across the Scala community. Those standards would be accompanied by the use of MiMa and human API design
column31: and would result in a semantic version scheme to rule them all.  In any case
column32: as this is still a pipe dream and I\'m sure not all projects will be on board
column33: we better allow what Eugene said: let every module define how its version number should be interpreted for eviction.  Finally
column34: my last comment: all this happens because people don\'t take binary and source compatibility seriously. That has to change. Otherwise
column35: we\'ll continue in the same situation forever."'

column10: b"b'  @jvican Can you be much more specific about what you mean by far from perfect? MiMa is probably the most successful scala project of which I am aware. What are the binary changes which will not be caught?'"
b'b\' @paulp What I meant is that we cannot unconditionally rely on MiMa to version jars. There has to be "human reasoning" about every change to the codebase
column11: assumption that brings me to favor semantic versioning as I propose it in my last comment. I like to use MiMa to double-check the implications of some changes
column12: rather than to decide whether I should bump a major or a minor number of a jar revision.  There have recently been several  negatives in MiMa (less than half a year ago):   1. url  1. url  1. url  1. url   These bugs tell me to be careful when using MiMa
column13: since I take bincompat seriously and cannot prove the absence of more of them. These are (normal) misbehaviours of a complex tool trying to solve a challenging task
column14: so I don\\\'t think MiMa is to blame. In fact
column15: I\\\'m surprised there are so few bugs for the inherent level of complexity MiMa is coping with. I think it\\\'s an *excellent* tool -I agree with your statement.  To sum up
column16: my only point is that: is not enough.\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m not sure that it can work with aliases. So before
column11: cross building was dumb
column12: it changed the scala version build wide
column13: even if some sub projects didn\\\'t support that scala version. Then it would issue the "thing" that the user requested
column14: be it a command
column15: task or alias
column16: build wide.  If some sub projects didn\\\'t support that scala version (eg
column17: because they were an sbt plugin and so could only build against Scala 2.10)
column18: then everything would blow up. So now
column19: when you tell it to cross build
column20: for each scala version
column21: it will gather all the sub projects that can be built against that scala version (based on their own crossScalaVersion setting)
column22: set the scala version for those projects
column23: and then issue the specified task against each of those projects.  That\\\'s the change that\\\'s causing this
column24: the thing the user requests has to be a task
column25: it can\\\'t be a command or an alias (which I\\\'m guessing is just a dynamically configured command
column26: I haven\\\'t actually looked at how aliases are configured)
column27: since commands and aliases don\\\'t get scoped to projects. My thoughts on this cross building commands or aliases is not something we want to support since the definition of what cross building is now doesn\\\'t make sense in that context.  So I\\\'d say it\\\'s not a bug or a regression
column28: but rather a by design change in behaviour that was necessary to make cross building intelligent

Builds the previously defined a "validate" or "verify" alias to call a sequence of tasks would have to define "validate" and "verify" as a task now instead (probably using ).\''

column11: and I stand by it as a superior behavior compared to 0.13\'s
column12: but I have to own up to the fact that it occasionally bites people
column13: at least when they try to composed it with commands -something ppl do often for release. I am reopening this with Documentation tag.  To be closed when the release note is updated.  "'

column12: then just implement the old behaviour
column13: changing the scala version at the build level. We could even do some validation in there
column14: so if it is running a command
column15: but it finds that different sub projects have different cross build versions
column16: we can warn the user about the potential unexpected behaviour that they\'ll get when cross building is done at the build level not on a per project level."'

column10: b'b\' Hey Eugene
column11: thank you for taking the time to think about this. Regarding your questions I think they are all answered with "yes". It means that there is no way for someone: (1) to trigger the task from the shell
column12: (2) refer to it inside their own settings or tasks
column13: and (3) to see it listed under help and get it auto-completed. These  are only there to be used from within the plugin code. Now
column14: a natural question for you to ask is: "Why don\\\'t you define them to be just constants and functions?" Well
column15: I want these  to be executed in the right . So if my private task asks for the name or the version or classpath or whatever
column16: I want it to get the values defined by the scope it currently runs on. So if it\\\'s called on a subproject it will behave differently than if it get\\\'s called from ThisBuild
column17: etc. Probably
column18: I can just define these as functions and then make sure I pass the proper arguments to them all the way
column19: but (personally I feel that) defining them as  makes it a bit more idiomatic sbt? I would love to hear your thoughts. \''

column10: b'b"  As of now (sbt 0.13.x or sbt 1.0.0-M5)
column11: sbt does not change behavior from one plugin to another
column12: so sbt defining a built-in settings are no different from the user rewriting it using a plugin or in terms of the semantics. It\'s just the matter of scoping and loading order. Changing this to introduce a notion of plugin privacy would be a major change
column13: so tbh I doubt it will happen anytime soon.  What you could try to do is make it very difficult for someone to define the setting by using package-private class."'

column10: b"b'  ... which works
column11: except for the fact that you can reference to the setting or task by using its id:  . But yes
column12: this is the way to go
column13: just wanted to point out its limitations.  I side with @eed3si9n
column14: your idea is good @imarios
column15: but it would provoke major changes in the plugin ecosystem and the whole sbt way to reason about
column16: so I would prefer to revisit this in the future.  However
column17: it seems that part of your proposal is to make those settings invisible to the end users. To accomodate that use case
column18: we could add an annotation that will prevent that setting from being shown in the autocompletion and traces. Would that address at least some of the current inconvenience @imarios?   '"

column10: b'b\' guys thank you very much for listening. @eed3si9n: I understand that this might be quite bit of a change
column11: and obviously this is not a deal breaker. However
column12: just for the record: I  found at least two other developers on SO and gitter that had the same question
column13: so this might be fairly popular question among plugin authors.  @jvican: That would really be helpful! If I don\\\'t tell my users the settings are there and they cannot autocomplete them and they need to use the TaskKey("myPrivateKey") to get it working then that would solve 99% of what I worry about. So that would be amazing! let me get this right.   Does this means that myPrivateKey should not be visible from sbt shell of the projects that use this plugin? \''

column10: b'b"  Yes
column11: we should post this information in the docs and link to this thread too.  @imarios I think it\'s okay to define inside
column12: that will prevent plugin authors from importing that value from  .  The other thing you need to take care of is the sbt shell. By default
column13: the commands that show and inspect the settings will show your private setting no matter if it\'s private or not.  To my surprise
column14: however
column15: I have stumbled upon something that may be *really* useful here: the concept of local settings and tasks. Those local settings and tasks
column16: to my best knowledge
column17: fulfill your need: they are invisible (i.e. not shown on inspect and completions).  In
column18: you have an example of how they are used:  At compile-time
column19: will have a generated free name (this is created in
column20: inside  )
column21: so local settings and tasks don\'t have a name
column22: only an identifier where they are created.  It seems that local settings and tasks were hacked to support files and it seems that they do exactly what you want.  I suggest that you: * Play around with local tasks. * Put them in a place where they are only accessible to your plugin
column24: let me know if this works for you."'

column10: b'b" Zinc sometimes doesn\'t invalidate files where trait definitions are inherited"'
b'b" Ok
column11: I don\'t have a nice and minimal test case for you guys
column12: unfortunately
column13: but I do have a reproducer.  It seems like this issue is broadly related to the cake pattern
column14: which is used heavily in some older parts of the quasar codebase (sadface\\xe2\\x80\\xa6).  Changing upstream functions (in inherited traits) will cause some downstream compilation units to explode at runtime with due to Zinc improperly believing the files in question did not need to be invalidated.  This happens intermittently in local development (my steps below point to a changeset which will reproduce the issue) and 100% deterministically in CI.  The reason it is happening deterministically in CI is because we cache our target directories for PR builds in Travis (as discussed with @jvican) in order to bring down our horrendously-long compilation times.  This worked almost flawlessly with SBT 0.13.x for the last eight months (we only needed to cache flush twice)
column15: which is quite impressive!  However
column16: on SBT 1.0
column17: we can\'t even get a single PR build to work
column18: as the slower matrix builds will get the new caches from the faster builds
column19: and themselves run into mutual-invalidation issues.  This is kind of an edge case
column20: but it does demonstrate how much less reliable current Zinc is from its state in 0.13.  ## steps  1. Clone [my fork of quasar]url  2. Check out commit 3. Run 4. Check out commit 5. Run  ## notes  sbt version: 1.0.2"'

column11: but it is that compiler which is in play."'

column11: zinc would discover only top-level objects and classes containing tests to the test framework. In 1.x
column12: however
column13: zinc can discover also nested objects and classes; that causes the "name" of a ClassLike to no longer be usable for reflection.  This change filters out nested  from the list
column14: restoring compatibility with 0.13. A zinc extension of ClassLike will probably be introduced in 1.1 or 1.2
column15: in order to provide the test framework with enough information to deal with nested classes.  This patch unblocks url  \''

b"b' copy resources directory BEFORE compiling'"
b"b' Although sbt adds the target directory to the classpath of the compiler
column11: this causes problems if the compiler needs access to resources because they are only copied AFTER (or in parallel with) the compile. Therefore you can get a situation where compile fails the first time
column12: then succeeds.  To avoid this
column13: I recommend that resources are copied BEFORE compilation.  Original report below
column14: which slightly misunderstood the root cause.   Unfortunately
column15: sbt puts test resources on the classpath in but not  . Compiler plugins and macros that access resources will therefore fail without this fix: '"

column10: b"b' are main resources on the classpath of  ?'"
b"b'  I agree. we should definitely explore this.'"
b'b" @dwijnand I found the real cause of this and changed the initial report accordingly. It\'s an sbt bug hopefully with an easy fix."'
b"b' cool
column11: I can actually tell you exactly where this happens (AFAIK). what a rare occurrence.  url for any potential contributor: you need to make the task depends on the completion of the task.'"

column10: b'b\' Currently the compilation and resource (potentially generation in case of web apps etc) copying are two independent tasks (i.e. "concurrent" in Lamport sense). This is by design.  Simply making task depend on introduces extra step to that were not previously there
column11: and therefore might incur expensive performance penalty. (Think Windows machine copying 100MB etc) If someone need resource during compilation
column12: it probably should be an opt-in process
column13: not a default behavior. \''

column11: but it\\\'s not the whole issue.  The recommended custom test configuration with shared sources is documented here: url According to that doc
column12: we should only need to copy over  . As I mentioned in the original report
column13: yes
column14: we can workaround the issue by importing the full
column15: but that overwrites settings unnecessarily.  The issue I reported here is that is not being set correctly when using the recommended configuration from the documentation. In particular
column16: the scoping of seems to be the issue.  If you\\\'re saying that now we must override the compilation and packaging tasks
column17: then the documented example for sharing sources should be corrected. I would argue
column18: though
column19: that it would be more ideal to fix the scoping of to avoid having to redefine  brought in by  .\''

column10: b'b"  That\'s correct. I would prefer removing that section or change it to the example I wrote above. This has two reasons  1. [The plugin best practices]url  are relatively new and I agree with the style that is recommended there.  This is mostly due to my experience with configurations
column11: which should be used in a very narrow use case. Separating tests is IMHO not a good use case. User usually struggle enough with scoping. When a basic task such as running tests requires are deep understanding of sbt to configure something
column12: then we should avoid this.  2. Overriding all settings with makes things more explicit and easier to debug
column13: because settings are selected from one configuration and not partially from two. This is again from my personal experience with scoping that at time can be very confusing For me this is a symptom of the documented way. If we recommend users to use partial settings
column14: we can break any setting at any time when changing some of the defaults. So rather than fixing symptoms I would like to recommend a more explicit style of configurations and try to steer users away from configurations. The only thing required to share tests is overriding the  . I would change the docs to this
column15: if this makes sense to you :smile: "'

column10: b'b"  While normally
column11: I\'d agree. The reason we use a separate configuration (and why I assume the docs do too) is to allow for different and parallel execution settings. Also
column12: we use multiple frameworks
column13: so bundling everything under a config makes things nice and easy to maintain. If there\'s a better way
column14: I\'d love to know about it.  We still use ScalaTest tagging to control which tests to run
column15: but we also modify
column18: and for the different configs. If we could simply create new tests tasks with these settings overridden and avoid all the scoping issues that would be great. I totally agree
column19: but you also now have the situation where SBT regressed and broke things for users. The documented way to do things is broken and has been broken for a long time. I\'m not sure what the policy is for regressions
column20: but shouldn\'t there be an actual fix (updated docs or a code fix) before closing this? The reason why I\'m arguing for a code fix is simply that this is a regression and deprecations should happen with warning. Makes sense
column21: but we actually have to do quite a bit more. We have a semi-complicated multi-project build and we rely on the inheritance of settings via configurations to set and similar settings at the highest level so the other configurations inherit it automatically. We would now have to override these settings for every single configuration instead of the just base configuration. We could explicitly call to the base settings for anything we override in our custom
column22: but I\'d argue that\'s no better than the partial settings issue you identified. Finally
column23: while I don\'t disagree with the overall sentiment
column24: part of the reason why I care so much about this is I\'m on a quest to reduce the number of explicit settings we have. Our SBT load times are terrible and while I know there are much bigger optimizations SBT needs to make
column25: one thing I can control is the number of settings that have to be resolved for each project."'

This example is a little surprising:  ****   The error message contains the incorrectly guessed configuration id although this may just be a difference between the error message and what it actually uses to resolve the key since the first one ought to fail if it was caused by a bad guess.'"

column10: b'b" The resolution for a works in the build because it resolves it against the map of other  \'s and so it succeeds even though the contains the name rather than the id. This is done in  .  The error message is using to display the referenced key which guessed the id.  There are a few options: 1. Do nothing more. Plugin authors can override or users can add the configuration via  . 2. Add a warning when we encounter that contains a configuration axis that is not in the project\'s configurations. Same workaround as 1. 3. Change to include the id and the name. Maintaining backwards compatibility will mean making a few guesses for the id which is no worse than what it does now. Should solve the problem reported here since the known keys in the project settings are likely to come from a which does have the id. 4. Allow configuration names to be used when parsing keys."'

It would be my last choice. 2. This seems possible with the changes I have made to the  . column10: b"b' @eatkins and I discussed this at length in sbt meeting today. There are various small workarounds we can try to reduce the pressure on Metaspace (a space in the native heap of Java Virtual Machine where class metadata is stored)
column11: but we agreed that we need to _remove_ the use of from launchers and launch scripts since it aggravates the problem by putting an arbitrary limit.  The problem in the short term might be that build users will continue to run script from sbt 1.2.8 etc. In those cases
column12: a workaround might be to specify equaling the total heap.'"

column10: b"b' So
column11: it is not a leak
column12: but it just requires more memory than 1.2.8?'"

column10: b"b' Not necessarily. Metaspace is a native memory region in the jvm. We have very little insight into what is occupying memory in there or if that memory is even used. I have detected very little difference in process heap
column11: virtual or resident memory utilization comparing 1.2.8 and 1.3.0. In spite of that
column12: 1.3.0 will require a much higher value for MaxMetaspaceSize or it will crash. We do not fully understand why that is
column13: but the jvm default for MaxMetaspaceSize is unlimited so we decided it made sense to revert to the default.'"

column10: b"b' One potential explanation is that sbt 1.3.0 loads more number of classes for whatever reasons
column11: and require higher water mark. This could be because we introduced lm-coursier with shaded third-party libraries
column12: different ClassLoader mechanisms
column13: etc. But that pressure on Metaspace might be a temporary thing during task execution (this is consistent with it getting triggered by  )
column14: and it may or may not matter in the grand scheme of things.'"
